State Park: Admiral William Standley State Recreation Area
Remarks: Boasts redwoods plus salmon and steelhead fishing on the Eel River.[2]
Preserves a wilderness of freshwater springs and geologically recent lava flows.[3]
Preserves a tule marsh and ancient archaeological sites of the Pomo people.[4]
Offers a primitive walk-in campground on the Big Sur coast.[5]
Interprets an island in San Francisco Bay whose history encompasses Coast Miwok prehistory, ranching, the 1910–1940 Angel Island Immigration Station, and long military use.[6]
Encompasses Año Nuevo Island and Año Nuevo Point, which boasts the world's largest mainland rookery of northern elephant seals.[7]
Showcases the state's most-consistent blooms of California poppy, in the high Mojave Desert.[8]

State Park: Antelope Valley Indian Museum State Historic Park
Remarks: Interprets the Native American cultures of the Great Basin and surrounding regions in a 1928 folk art building on the NRHP.[9]
Preserves a vast tract of the Colorado Desert in California's largest state park.[10]
Preserves a grove of coast redwoods.[11]

State Park: Arthur B. Ripley Desert Woodland State Park
Remarks: Preserves a remnant stand of Joshua trees and junipers in the Antelope Valley.[12]
Balances protection of rocky coast and dune habitat with public access.[13] The 1913 Asilomar Conference Grounds are a National Historic Landmark.[14]
Offers numerous recreational opportunities along the North and Middle Forks of the American River.[15]
Features a rugged wilderness on Austin Creek, adjacent to Armstrong Redwoods State Natural Reserve.[16]
Harbors a profusion of spring-blooming western azaleas.[17]

State Park: Bale Grist Mill State Historic Park
Remarks: Showcases a restored 1846 water-powered grist mill in Napa Valley.[18] The mill is on the NRHP.[19]
Offers fishing and beachcombing among tide pools.[20]
Centers on a reservoir on the South Fork Eel River.[21]
Interprets the third and oldest-surviving California capitol, used 1853–54.[22] The building is on the NRHP.[19]
Preserves a tidal wetland on the Carquinez Strait.[23]
Offers windsurfing and other water recreation on the Bethany Reservoir.[24]
Offers tours of the 1868 Victorian mansion of influential settlers John and Annie Bidwell.[25] The mansion is on the NRHP.
Preserves riparian habitat on the Sacramento River and its tributary Big Chico Creek.[26]
Established as California's first state park, to preserve coast redwoods on Waddell Creek.[27]
Preserves the ghost town of Bodie, whose gold-mining heyday ran from 1877 to 1881, and is now a National Historic Landmark.[28]
Offers surf fishing and catching grunion by hand.[29]
Occupies the southwesternmost point of the contiguous U.S., on the Mexico – United States border. Part of the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve.[30]
Contains the farthest inland coast redwoods in a California state park.[31]
Offers water recreation amid a maze of channels in the Sacramento–San Joaquin River Delta.[32]
Encompasses a hidden valley with a historic ranch established in 1857.[33]
Offers 6 miles (9.7 km) of unpaved roadway for hiking and cross-country skiing.[34]
Showcases a secluded redwood-filled valley.[35]
In development, not open to public
Protects two large groves of giant sequoias.[36]
Interprets the influence of the state's citrus industry.[37]

State Park: California Indian Heritage Center State Park
Remarks: Undeveloped property located in West Sacramento. Plan is for this unit to eventually replace the State Indian Museum (State Historic Park).[38]
Offers exhibits and tours of the California State Capitol and its grounds.[39]

State Park: California State Mining and Mineral Museum
Remarks: Exhibits the official state mineral collection and displays on the region's influential mining heritage.[40]
California State Parks' first state marine park.
Constitutes California's first urban state recreation area, on the west shore of San Francisco Bay.[41]
Provides a sandy, warm-water beach outside San Diego.[42]
Features a small beach at the foot of coastal bluffs.[43]
Protects a 1-mile-long (1.6 km) beach and a lagoon at the mouth of the Carmel River which attracts many migratory birds.[44]
Provides off-roading opportunities in the Diablo Range around the former townsite of Carnegie.[45]
Offers a mile-long beach in the city of Carpinteria.[46]
Preserves a small strip of rugged coastline.[47]
Features 29 miles (47 km) of shoreline on Castaic Lake.[48]
Provides access to the Castle Crags Wilderness, with its 6,000-foot-tall (1,800 m) rock crags.[49]

County: Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, and San Mateo
Remarks: Encompasses a wild forest with rock climbing opportunities along the crest of the Santa Cruz Mountains.[50]
Preserves a riparian forest along the Stanislaus River.[51]
Provides a swimming and surfing beach in the beach town of Cayucos.[52]
Surrounds an 1880s Chinese American shrimp-fishing village and salt marshes on San Pablo Bay.[53]
Preserves a large tract of the Chino Hills.[54]

State Park: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
Remarks: Preserves a sandstone cave bearing rock art of the Chumash people.[55]

State Park: Clay Pit State Vehicular Recreation Area
Remarks: Provides off-roading opportunities in the shallow clay pit excavated for material to build the Oroville Dam.[56]
Provides recreation opportunities on the southwest shore of Clear Lake, the largest freshwater lake within California's borders.[57]
Interprets the town of Allensworth, founded in 1908 as a haven for African Americans by Colonel Allen Allensworth and other community leaders.[58] The town is a district on the NRHP.
Interprets Columbia's preserved Gold Rush-era downtown,[59] a National Historic Landmark District.
Adjoins a stretch of the Sacramento River known for its fishing.[60]
Provides a half-mile-long swimming beach adjacent to the Newport Beach harbor jetty.[61]
Encompasses cliffbound coastline, inland chaparral canyons, and the NRHP-listed Crystal Cove Historic District of 1920s and 30s beach cottages.[62]
Preserves an expansive tract of forests and meadows above 5,000 feet (1,500 m) in the Laguna Mountains, on the former Rancho Cuyamaca.[63]
Features a balancing rock and the Rubicon Point Light on the shore of Lake Tahoe.[64]

State Park: Del Norte Coast Redwoods State Park
Remarks: Preserves old-growth coast redwoods and is managed cooperatively with RNSP.[65]
Preserves undeveloped wet meadows and sloughs in the Sacramento–San Joaquin River Delta. Closed to the public.[66]
Features 3 miles (4.8 km) of beach and a hang gliding training site, adjacent to Los Angeles International Airport.
Offers surfing and beach-front camping in Dana Point.[67]
Interprets the site where the Donner Party was trapped by weather in the Sierra Nevada during the winter of 1846–1847,[68] now a National Historic Landmark.

State Park: Ed Z'berg Sugar Pine Point State Park
Remarks: Comprises the Lake Tahoe estate and 1903 summer home of banker Isaias W. Hellman.[69]
Features a narrow beach at the foot of coastal bluffs where monarch butterflies congregate in autumn.[70]

State Park: El Presidio de Santa Barbara State Historic Park
Remarks: Preserves components of a Spanish presidio dating back to 1782,[71] now on the NRHP.
Contains Lake Tahoe's Emerald Bay and Fannette Island plus the 1929 Vikingsholm mansion,[72] which is on the NRHP.

Preserves a marsh on San Francisco Bay, managed as part of McLaughlin Eastshore State Park. Closed to the public. Unit will not become officially classified until action is also taken by the California Fish and Game Commission (ongoing since 2004).
Contains a surfing beach and an estuary at the mouth of the Ventura River.
Offers tours of an underground gold mine which operated from 1850 to 1956, plus its surface surroundings.[73] The mine is on the NRHP.
Preserves diverse coastal habitats on Estero Bay.
Surrounds Folsom and Natoma Lakes, reservoirs on the American River.[74]
Interprets an 1895 hydroelectricity plant, now a National Historic and Historic Civil Engineering Landmark.[75]

State Park: The Forest of Nisene Marks State Park
Remarks: Preserves a tract of secondary forest donated by the family of former owner Nisene Marks.[76]

Situated on its commanding bluff adjacent to Humboldt Bay, park interprets relations between U.S. army (present at fort 1853–1870), Native American groups, and settlers. Site includes a logging museum and logging equipment displays.[77]
Reclaims coastline overlooking Monterey Bay on former property of the decommissioned Fort Ord.[78]

Interprets the partially reconstructed Fort Ross, an 1812–1841 Russian-American Company outpost that was the southernmost settlement in the Russian colonization of the Americas.[79] The fort is a National Historic Landmark.
Interprets the U.S. Army fort staffed 1854–1864 to monitor the Sebastian Indian Reservation.[80] The fort is on the NRHP.
Encompasses a flooded area in the Sacramento–San Joaquin River Delta accessible only by water.[81]
Provides views of the surrounding landscape from atop Fremont Peak and of the night sky from the Fremont Peak Observatory.[82]
Preserves a largely hidden stretch of wild coast.[83]
Flanks the narrow gorge of Gaviota Creek, which funnels Sundowner winds onto the popular beach area.[84]

State Park: George J. Hatfield State Recreation Area
Remarks: Adjoins the Merced River.[85]
Interprets the 1877 mansion that housed 13 of California's governors and their families from 1903 to 1967.[86]
Embraces a steep-walled cove, near the Devil's Slide, where gray whales are often seen close to shore.[87]
Preserves a remnant of the native grasslands once extensive in the Central Valley.[88]
Features a picturesque beach in Elk and a visitor center interpreting the town's lumbering history.[89]
Harbors groves of coast redwoods in three separate units along the Van Duzen River.[90]
Boasts hot springs that feed a swimming pool complex in an alpine meadow.[91]
Encompasses four popular sandy beaches on Half Moon Bay.[92]
Preserves an undeveloped parcel of Pacific coast.

State Park: Harry A. Merlo State Recreation Area
Remarks: Offers fishing on Big Lagoon adjacent to Humboldt Lagoons State Park
Preserves a canyon in Carmel saved from a planned freeway route. In development, not open to public.

State Park: Hearst San Simeon State Historical Monument
Remarks: Offers tours of newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst's opulent 115-room "Hearst Castle," designed by architect Julia Morgan between 1919 and 1947.[93]
Preserves rocky coast and rare habitats like mima mounds and Monterey pine forest, as well as a 5,850-year-old Native American archaeological site.[94]

State Park: Heber Dunes State Vehicular Recreation Area
Remarks: Attracts ATV riders to sandy, tamarisk-dotted dunes along a former course of the Alamo River.[95]
Preserves two groves of old-growth coast redwoods in the Anderson Valley.[96]
Boasts its Redwood Grove and other old-growth forest.[97]
Encompasses a sprawling wilderness of ridges and steep canyons in the Diablo Range.[98]

State Park: Hollister Hills State Vehicular Recreation Area
Remarks: Offers a variety of off-roading tracks and events in the hills outside Hollister.[99]
Protects part of the largest lagoon system in the United States, including Big Lagoon, Stone Lagoon, and Freshwater Lagoon.[100]
Preserves the world's largest remaining old-growth coast redwood forest,[101] including Stratosphere Giant, the fourth-tallest known tree.

State Park: Hungry Valley State Vehicular Recreation Area
Remarks: Offers 130 miles (210 km) of off-highway tracks, connecting to more routes in Los Padres National Forest.[102]
Contains 2 miles (3.2 km) of wide, flat beach in the city of Huntington Beach.[103]

State Park: Indian Grinding Rock State Historic Park
Remarks: Interprets an outcrop with 1,185 mortar holes where Native Americans ground acorns into flour.[104]
Harbors a profusion of California fan palms growing along the San Andreas Fault in the Indio Hills. Part of the multi-agency Coachella Valley Preserve.[105]

Contains several structures from the ranch of author Jack London and his wife Charmian London, as well as their grave. The ranch is a National Historic Landmark.[106] Currently managed by the Jack London Park Partners, a non-profit that takes no state funding to maintain the park.
Honors explorer Jedediah Smith with a tract of coast redwoods along the Smith River. Part of Redwood National and State Parks.[107]

State Park: John B. Dewitt Redwoods State Natural Reserve
Remarks: Contains three undeveloped coast redwood groves split off from Humboldt Redwoods State Park in 2001.[108] In development, not open to the public.
Protects rugged cliffs on the Big Sur coast flanking the mouth of a creek.[109]
Interprets a series of marine terraces each exhibiting a different stage of ecological succession.[110]
Stretches from the Big Sur coast up to 3,000-foot (910 m) ridges.[111] Includes the iconic seaside McWay Falls.
Offers urban open space in the Baldwin Hills of Los Angeles.[112]
Encompasses 700 feet (210 m) of lakefront on the north shore of Lake Tahoe.[113]
Harbors a secondary forest with spring-blooming rhododendrons adjacent to Salt Point State Park.[114]

State Park: La Purísima Mission State Historic Park
Remarks: Contains the 1813 La Purisima Mission, the most completely restored Spanish mission in California.[115]

State Park: Lake Del Valle State Recreation Area
Remarks: Surrounds Lake Del Valle, a reservoir on the Arroyo Valle managed by the East Bay Regional Park District
Surrounds Lake Oroville, a reservoir on the Feather River.[116]
Contains the southernmost reservoir in the 701-mile (1,128 km) California State Water Project and the Ya'i Heki' Regional Indian Museum.[117]
Offers an 18-hole golf course in the High Sierras.[118]

State Park: Leland Stanford Mansion State Historic Park
Remarks: Offers tours of governor and tycoon Leland Stanford's restored 1856 mansion, now a National Historic Landmark.[119]
Honors actor and conservationist Leo Carrillo with a 1.5-mile (2.4 km) beach. Part of Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area.[120]
Comprises a small, rocky beach in Encinitas.[121]
Features the Steamer Lane surf break and a lighthouse containing the Santa Cruz Surfing Museum.[122]
Contains four lime kilns from an 1887 lime-smelting operation on the Big Sur coast.[123]
Comprises a broad open beach with dunes.[124]
Provides urban open space on the site of an 1875 train station where many travelers first arrived in Los Angeles.[125]

State Park: Los Osos Oaks State Natural Reserve

Remarks: Preserves the largest hydraulic mining site in California.

State Park: Marconi Conference Center State Historic Park

Remarks: Features Stone House of John Marsh;Park is under construction and closed to public as of 2023.

State Park: Marshall Gold Discovery State Historic Park
Remarks: Marks the discovery of gold by James W. Marshall at Sutter's Mill in 1848, sparking the California Gold Rush.

State Park: Martial Cottle Park State Recreation Area
McLaughlin Eastshore State Park State Seashore
Remarks: Encompasses several remnant and restored parcels along the East Bay waterfront.
Includes 40 miles (64 km) of shoreline on Millerton Lake and the 1867 Millerton County Courthouse.[127]

State Park: Mono Lake Tufa State Natural Reserve
Oceano Dunes State Vehicular Recreation Area
Ocotillo Wells State Vehicular Recreation Area
Remarks: Offers off-roading opportunities adjacent to Anza-Borrego Desert State Park.[128]

Includes the California State Railroad Museum which celebrates the history of rail transportation in California with museum displays, 21 restored locomotives, and a heritage railway along the Sacramento River.[129]

State Park: Old Town San Diego State Historic Park
Pigeon Point Light Station State Historic Park
Point Cabrillo Light Station State Historic Park

Remarks: In development, not open to public
Contains the still-operational 1889 Point Sur Lighthouse and a former U.S. Navy SOSUS base. The lighthouse is on the NRHP.[130]

State Park: Prairie City State Vehicular Recreation Area
Remarks: Offers open off-roading at the foot of the Sierra Nevada as well as a go-kart track and 4WD obstacle course. This unit has never been officially named and 'Prairie City' is used until official action.[131]
Closed to the public
Comprises the grand 1849 hacienda of the prominent Castro family on their Rancho San Andrés.[132] In development, not open to public. The hacienda is on the NRHP.
Preserves a parcel of old-growth redwoods and Douglas fir beside U.S. Route 101. The campground was removed in 1976.[133]

State Park: Rio de Los Angeles State Park State Recreation Area
Robert H. Meyer Memorial State Beach
Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach
San Juan Bautista State Historic Park
San Luis Reservoir State Recreation Area
San Pasqual Battlefield State Historic Park
Santa Cruz Mission State Historic Park
Santa Susana Pass State Historic Park

Remarks: Interprets the diverse cultures of the indigenous peoples of California.[134]
Formerly Patrick's Point State Park
Managed by a group of Sonoma County non-profits as Team Sugarloaf with no state funding.

In development on the north side of the Sutter Buttes. This park has not officially been named but has been classified as a state park. The use of Sutter Buttes in the name was allowed temporarily by the California State Parks Commission in 2004. Currently no public access.[135]
Campground on Lake Tahoe[136]
Open under National Park Service management
Supports a variety of day-use activities at the northern end of Sonoma Valley.[137]
Preserves beach, bog, and a pygmy forest on the site of a former redwood lumbering settlement.[138] The pygmy forest is a National Natural Landmark.[139]

State Park: Wassama Round House State Historic Park
Watts Towers of Simon Rodia State Historic Park
Weaverville Joss House State Historic Park

Remarks: In development

State Park: William B. Ide Adobe State Historic Park
Woodland Opera House State Historic Park
